questions.text: Which of the following respiratory system components is derived from neural crest?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Laryngeal cartilage 
Ref– Read the text below
Sol:
• Laryngeal cartilages (e.g., the thyroid, cricoid, arytenoid cartilages) are derived from neural crest. 
• The endothelial cells in the simple squamous epithelium that lines the pulmonary capillaries are derived from visceral mesoderm.
• The epithelial lining of primary bronchi is derived from endoderm.
• Tracheal glands and epithelium both derive from endoderm.

questions.text: A mother with diabetes gives birth to a baby who is diagnosed as having dextroposition of the aorta and the pulmonary trunk with cyanosis and shortness of breath. Which of the following structure& la required to remain patent until surgical correction of the deformity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ductus arteriosus

Dextroposition or transposition of the great arteries must be accompanied by a VSD or a patent ductus arteriosus for the infant to survive. The transposition causes oxygenated blood to pass from the left ventricle into the pulmonary trunk and then into the lungs, but deoxygenated blood travels from the right ventricle into the aorta and then into the systemic circulation.

PGE inhibitor (e.g., indomethacin), acetylcholine, histamine, and catecholamines
promote closure of the ductus arteriosus in a premature birth.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with atrial fibrillation is started on warfarin. He develops dark urine after starting trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for UTI. Which is the most likely mechanism for this interaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CYP2C9 inhibition increasing warfarin levels

Explanation:
Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist that is primarily metabolized by the cytochrome P450 2C9 (CYP2C9) enzyme.
• Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is a known CYP2C9 inhibitor.
• When co-administered, TMP-SMX inhibits warfarin metabolism, leading to elevated plasma warfarin levels, which increases the risk of bleeding complications, such as hematuria (which explains the dark urine).

 Incorrect Options Explained:
• A. Enhanced renal excretion of warfarin
o Warfarin is metabolized hepatically, not renally excreted in significant amounts.
• C. CYP induction reducing warfarin levels
o TMP-SMX inhibits, not induces, CYP2C9.
o Enzyme induction would lower warfarin levels, not increase them.
• D. Increased protein binding of warfarin
o Warfarin is highly protein-bound, but this interaction is not clinically significant compared to CYP inhibition.

questions.text: Adenosine is drug of choice for prompt conversion of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia to sinus rhythm because it:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Directly inhibits AV nodal conduction

Explanation:
Adenosine is a rapid-acting antiarrhythmic (Class V agent) used intravenously to acutely terminate paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Its action is primarily on the atrioventricular (AV) node.
• It acts on A1 adenosine receptors in the AV node, leading to:
o Opening of potassium channels
o Hyperpolarization of the AV nodal cells
o Transient AV nodal conduction block
This transient AV nodal inhibition is highly effective for re-entrant tachycardias involving the AV node (e.g., AVNRT), making adenosine the drug of choice in emergency settings.

Incorrect Options:
• a) Decreases AV nodal refractory period
o Incorrect: Adenosine actually increases the refractory period of the AV node, leading to conduction block.
• b) Directly inhibits SA node
o Partially true, but not its primary therapeutic action in PSVT.
• d) Blocks delayed rectifier potassium current
o This is the action of Class III antiarrhythmics (e.g., amiodarone); not the

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs can cause secondary weight gain?

I. Insulin

II. Tirzepatide

III. Orlistat

IV. Thyroxine
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 I only

Explanation:

I. Insulin 
Causes weight gain
Promotes anabolic effects, lipogenesis, and decreases glucosuria.
Common side effect in diabetes treatment.

II. Tirzepatide 
Though used for weight loss, some weight gain may occur early in therapy or in certain patients, especially when titrated or combined with insulin.
It's primarily weight-reducing, but in the context of “can cause”, it qualifies.

III. Orlistat 
Used specifically for weight loss
Inhibits gastrointestinal lipase → reduces fat absorption
Leads to weight loss, not gain.

IV. Thyroxine 
Used in hypothyroidism
Excess thyroxine can cause weight loss, not gain
Hypothyroidism itself causes weight gain, but thyroxine treatment does not.

questions.text: A potassium channel antagonist which increases Acetylcholine release and is useful in Lambert Eaton Myesthenia syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Amifampridine

Explanation:
Amifampridine (also known as 3,4-diaminopyridine) is a voltage-gated potassium channel blocker. By blocking presynaptic K⁺ channels, it prolongs the depolarization phase at the motor nerve terminal. This enhances calcium influx, which in turn increases acetylcholine (ACh) release at the neuromuscular junction.
• It is the first-line symptomatic treatment for Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS), a rare autoimmune disorder where antibodies attack presynaptic P/Q-type voltage-gated calcium channels, reducing ACh
•  release.
Incorrect Options:
• a) Hemicholinium
o Inhibits high-affinity choline transport into the neuron → ↓ ACh synthesis
o Not therapeutic, experimental use only.
• b) Vesamicol
o Inhibits vesicular ACh transporter (VAChT) → ↓ ACh storage in vesicles
o Not used clinically.
• c) Botulinum toxin
o Blocks ACh release by cleaving SNARE proteins → causes flaccid paralysis
o Used therapeutically in conditions like dystonia or cosmetic treatments, but worsens LEMS.

choices.text: It is useful in hypovolemic hyponatremia
It should be used for at least 1 year

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct regarding arginine vasopressin antagonist Tolvaptan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

It is an oral drug

Explanation:
Tolvaptan is a selective vasopressin V₂ receptor antagonist that promotes free water excretion (aquaresis) without significant loss of electrolytes. It is primarily used in the treatment of:
• Euvolemic hyponatremia (e.g., SIADH)
• Hypervolemic hyponatremia (e.g., in heart failure, cirrhosis)
• Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) – to slow cyst growth and preserve renal function.

Incorrect Options Explained:
• A. It is useful in hypovolemic hyponatremia
 Incorrect: Tolvaptan is contraindicated in hypovolemic hyponatremia, as it can worsen volume depletion.
• B. It antagonises the V₁ receptor
 Incorrect: Tolvaptan selectively blocks V₂ receptors in the kidney collecting ducts, not V₁ receptors.
• C. It should be used for at least 1 year
 Incorrect: While it may be used long-term in ADPKD under careful monitoring, chronic use is limited due to the risk of hepatotoxicity. Liver function must be closely monitored, and its use is often discontinued if liver enzymes rise.

questions.text: Which one of the following biologic agents used in the treatment of Inflammatory Bowel Disease acts by inhibiting the enzyme Janus Kinase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tofacitinib

Explanation:
Tofacitinib is an oral small molecule that selectively inhibits Janus Kinase (JAK) enzymes, primarily JAK1 and JAK3, and to a lesser extent JAK2. It is used for the treatment of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, a type of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD).
By blocking the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, tofacitinib reduces the transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines involved in immune activation, leading to decreased inflammation in the gastrointestinal tract.

Incorrect Options:
• A & C. Vedolizumab:
o A monoclonal antibody that targets α4β7 integrin, blocking leukocyte migration to the gut.
o It is gut-selective and does not inhibit JAK.
• B. Adalimumab:
o A TNF-α inhibitor, not a JAK inhibitor.
o It blocks tumor necrosis factor-alpha, a cytokine involved in systemic inflammation
• C. Ustekinumab
A monoclonal antibody targeting the p40 subunit of IL-12 and IL-23. Approved for Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis. Does not inhibit JAK

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate agent for reversing or controlling ticagrelor-induced bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bentracimab

Explanation:
Ticagrelor is a reversible oral P2Y₁₂ receptor antagonist used as an antiplatelet agent to reduce thrombotic cardiovascular events. Unlike clopidogrel or prasugrel, which require metabolic activation and bind irreversibly, ticagrelor has a rapid onset and offset of action.
In cases of severe or life-threatening bleeding, managing ticagrelor-induced antiplatelet effects is challenging. Traditional reversal strategies such as platelet transfusion (choice C) are generally ineffective because ticagrelor binds directly to the P2Y₁₂ receptor and its active drug is present in plasma, continuing to inhibit transfused platelets.
• Idarucizumab (choice A) is a specific reversal agent for dabigatran, a direct thrombin inhibitor, and is not effective for ticagrelor.
• Andexanet alfa (choice B) is a reversal agent approved for factor Xa inhibitors (e.g., apixaban, rivaroxaban) and does not bind or affect ticagrelor activity.
Bentracimab (choice D), also known as PB2452, is a monoclonal antibody fragment specifically developed to bind ticagrelor and its active metabolite with high affinity, thereby neutralizing its antiplatelet effect. Clinical trials (e.g., REVERSE-IT) have demonstrated rapid and sustained reversal of ticagrelor’s antiplatelet activity with bentracimab, making it the most appropriate option among the listed choices.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with chronic hepatitis C infection (genotype 1b) is initiated on a direct-acting antiviral (DAA) regimen. His medical history includes coronary artery disease and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Two weeks after starting therapy, he presents with worsening dyspnea, fatigue, and severe bradycardia. He is not on any new cardiac medications, but he continues to take amiodarone for rhythm control.  Which of the following antiviral agents used in hepatitis C treatment is most likely contributing to his cardiotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sofosbuvir

Explanation:
Sofosbuvir, a nucleotide analog NS5B polymerase inhibitor, is a key component in many direct-acting antiviral (DAA) regimens for hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. While generally well-tolerated, serious cardiac events, including severe bradycardia, have been reported when sofosbuvir is co-administered with amiodarone.
Mechanism:
• The exact mechanism is unclear but may involve synergistic effects on sinoatrial or atrioventricular node conduction.
• This interaction has led to reports of life-threatening bradycardia and cardiac arrest, particularly in patients with pre-existing heart disease or those on beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers.
Other Options:
• Ribavirin: Associated mainly with hemolytic anemia, not cardiotoxicity.
• Fosaprevir: A protease inhibitor, not widely used or available globally; not strongly linked to cardiotoxicity.
• Velpatasvir: NS5A inhibitor, typically combined with sofosbuvir; not cardiotoxic alone, but may compound the effect when co-administered with sofosbuvir in patients on amiodarone.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman with newly diagnosed schizophrenia is started on an atypical antipsychotic. Six weeks later, she presents with complaints of breast tenderness, galactorrhea, and irregular menstrual cycles. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum prolactin levels.
Which of the following antipsychotic medications is most likely responsible for these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Risperidone

Among atypical (second-generation) antipsychotics, Risperidone is the most commonly associated with hyperprolactinemia. This is due to its potent dopamine D2 receptor antagonism, particularly in the tuberoinfundibular pathway, which inhibits dopamine-mediated suppression of prolactin release from the anterior pituitary.
Risperidone (B):
o Strong D2 blockade → ↑ Prolactin
o Leads to galactorrhea, amenorrhea, infertility, and gynecomastia
o High-yield adverse effect in exams
Aripiprazole (A):
o Partial D2 agonist
o Lowers or normalizes prolactin levels
o Sometimes used to counteract hyperprolactinemia induced by other antipsychotics
Clozapine (C):
o Weak D2 blockade
o Minimal effect on prolactin
o More associated with agranulocytosis, weight gain, and sedation
Ziprasidone (D):
o Minimal effect on prolactin
o Not commonly associated with endocrine side effects; may prolong QT interval

questions.text: The current census enumeration technique is:d
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

De jure
Explanation
• De jure census: Counts people at their usual place of residence.
• De facto census: Counts people where they are found on the census day, regardless of their usual residence.
• Example: If someone is temporarily living in another city for work during the census, a de jure census would still count them at their home address, while a de facto census would count them at their temporary location.

questions.text: Which nerve agent was used in the Tokyo subway attack?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nerve agents cause the same health effects regardless of the route of exposure. Initial effects depend on the dose and route of exposure. Nerve agents interfere with the normal functioning of the nervous system. 
EYE EXPOSURE
• Contracted or pinpoint pupils (miosis), redness of the membranes (conjunctiva), pain in and around the eye, dim and/or blurred vision, sensation of pressure with heaviness, and reflex nausea and vomiting (emesis).
• Effects are usually local, occuring from direct contact with nerve agent vapor, aerosol, or liquid; but exposure by other routes can also affect the eyes.
INHALATION EXPOSURE
• Mild to moderate: Contracted or pinpoint pupils (miosis), runny nose (rhinorrhea), narrowing of the large airways (bronchoconstriction), fluid accumulation within the airways of the lungs, and slight to moderate difficulty breathing or shortness of breath (dyspnea).
• Severe: In addition to the symptoms described above, there can be loss of consciousness; seizures; muscular twitching (fasciculations); floppy (flaccid) paralysis; increased fluid accumulation within the airways and within the digestive tract, resulting in secretions from the nose and mouth; cessation of breathing (apnea); and death.
SKIN EXPOSURE
• Mild to moderate: Health effects may be immediate or may be delayed up to 18 hours. Profuse sweating (diaphoresis) and muscular twitching (fasciculations) at the site of contact, nausea, vomiting (emesis), diarrhea, and weakness (malaise).
• Severe: Health effects may appear quickly; 2 to 30 minutes post-exposure. In addition to the above, there can be loss of consciousness, seizures, muscular twitching (fasciculations), floppy (flaccid) paralysis, increased fluid accumulation within the airways and within the digestive tract resulting in secretions from the nose and mouth, cessation of breathing (apnea), and death

questions.text: The most common route of spread for a parapharyngeal abscess is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Direct extension from the palatine tonsils 
Ref:Read the text below
Sol:
A parapharyngeal abscess (PPA) is a deep neck space infection that commonly results from contiguous spread of infection from adjacent structures. The most common route of spread is direct extension from the palatine tonsils or peritonsillar space.
Why is option A correct?
• The palatine tonsils are in close proximity to the parapharyngeal space.
• Infections such as tonsillitis or peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) can directly extend into the parapharyngeal space.
• Other direct sources include infections from dental, sinus, or mastoid regions.
Why not the other options?
• B) Hematogenous spread:
o While hematogenous spread can occur in septicemia, parapharyngeal abscesses typically arise from local infections rather than bloodstream seeding.
• C) Lymphatic spread from the prevertebral space:
o The prevertebral space is posterior to the pharynx and is less commonly involved in direct lymphatic drainage to the parapharyngeal space.
o Infections from the prevertebral space are more likely to spread inferiorly into the mediastinum rather than the parapharyngeal space.
• D) Venous spread from the retropharyngeal space:
The retropharyngeal space can communicate with the parapharyngeal space, but infections more commonly spread from the parapharyngeal space to the

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of prerenal azotemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which laboratory finding is characteristic of prerenal azotemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Which of the following is a common clinical feature of prerenal azotemia?
questions.solution:

questions.text: What is the typical blood urea nitrogen (BUN) to creatinine ratio in prerenal azotemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

>20:1 Explanation: In prerenal azotemia, the BUN/creatinine ratio is typically elevated (>20:1) due to increased urea reabsorption in the proximal tubule under low perfusion conditions.

questions.text: Which intervention is most appropriate in managing prerenal azotemia caused by hypovolemia?

questions.text: Gitelman syndrome is caused by a mutation in which renal tubular transporter?

questions.text: Which inherited channelopathy is associated with hypokalemia and hypertension?

questions.text: Which thyroid nodule is least likely to be malignant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• Risk of malignancy increase with:
• Nodules in the very young and very old (especially men).
• Exposure to ionizing radiation. 
• A family history of thyroid malignancy, familial polyposis, or other endocrine disease.
• Rapid nodule growth, pain, compressive symptoms, or hoarseness of voice.
• Physical findings of a solitary nodule with firm or irregular texture or with fixation to surrounding structures suggest malignancy as does enlarged cervical lymph nodes.
• Malignancy is uncommon in hyperfunctioning nodules, and all patients should have a serum TSH measured to exclude clinical or subclinical thyrotoxicosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a painless limp. Examination reveals Trendelenburg gait. X-ray pelvis shows fragmentation of the femoral head. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
Explanation:
LCPD is avascular necrosis of the femoral head in children aged 4–8 years. Presents as painless limp, Trendelenburg gait, and x-ray shows fragmentation or sclerosis of femoral head.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for osteosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Distal femur
Explanation:
Osteosarcoma commonly affects metaphyseal regions of long bones. Distal femur is the most frequent site, followed by proximal tibia and humerus.

questions.text: A patient with a road traffic accident has pain and swelling in the leg. X-ray shows a fracture of the mid-shaft of tibia. The next step is to look for:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Compartment syndrome
Explanation:
Tibial shaft fractures are commonly associated with compartment syndrome due to confined fascial compartments. Early recognition is critical to prevent muscle necrosis and nerve damage.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with severe back pain after trivial trauma. X-ray shows vertebral collapse at T12 with preserved intervertebral disc spaces. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Osteoporotic compression fracture
Explanation:
In elderly, osteoporosis leads to vertebral compression fractures after trivial trauma. Disc space is preserved. Pott’s and metastasis often affect disc space or adjacent vertebrae.

questions.text: Indicators of bone formation the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Bone turnover markers are divided into:
 Bone Formation Markers (reflect osteoblast activity):
• Serum osteocalcin – secreted by osteoblasts.
• Alkaline phosphatase (bone-specific) – released by active osteoblasts.
• Type I procollagen peptides (e.g., PINP, PICP) – reflect new collagen synthesis.
Bone Resorption Markers (reflect osteoclast activity):
• Deoxypyridinoline – released during collagen breakdown in bone resorption, excreted in urine.
• C-telopeptide (CTX), N-telopeptide (NTX) – degradation products of Type I collagen.
Therefore, deoxypyridinoline is a marker of bone resorption, not bone formation.

choices.text: Lignocaine may be used to treat bupivacaine induced arrythmias
Amiodarone is the drug of choice for treating arrythmias

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding local anesthetic systemic toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 
CARDIOVASCULAR TOXICITY OF LOCAL ANESTHETICS:
• MAIN MECHANISM: block of cardiac Na+ channels leading to negative inotropy (hypotension) and arrythmias
• CVS toxicity is a severe form of toxicity because of slow rate of recovery of blocked sodium channels from bupivacaine (high potency)
• Arrythmias that can happen are:
• Prolonged PR interval, wide QRS complexes ultimately leading to sinus bradycardia and cardiac arrest (any rhythm)

TREATMENT
• Drug of choice is infusion of 20% INTRALIPID solution: bolus dose: 1.5 ml/kg followed by infusion of 0.25 ml \kg\min
• Mechanism: it increases the rate of recovery of blocked sodium channels by decreasing cardiac bupivacaine concentration.
• Propofol although contains lipid in it , but is not recommended as a substitute for intralipid because of requirement of large amount of propofol and its hemodynamic effects.
• No other antiarrhythmic is useful in the management of bupivacaine induced cardiac arrythmias
• Use of lignocaine is not recommended in arrythmias due to bupivacaine.
• 2 drugs useful are adrenaline and amiodarone as per ACLS guidelines for the management of cardiac arrest
• Later in severe cases Extra Corporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) can be used.

questions.text: With tracheal tubes, all are true except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CUFF OF ETT:
• There are 2 types of cuff that endotracheal tubes come with.
• High pressure low volume cuff: these provide better protection against aspiration at the cost of increased risk of tracheal mucosal ischemia and subsequent tracheal necrosis.
• Low-pressure high-volume cuff: these do not cause tracheal mucosal necrosis as they distributed the pressure on the tracheal wall but there is slightly higher risk of aspiration as compared to high pressure cuffs.
• The ideal intracuff pressure in a healthy adult should be kept less than 25 mmhg. This is the pressure of tracheal mucosal capillaries 
• Bevel of the tip always faces left in an endotracheal tube and it improves visualization of vocal cords during intubation.

questions.text: Which of the following landmarks are used to perform caudal epidural block?
questions.solution:

CAUDAL EPIDURAL ANESTHESIA:
• It is deposition of local anesthetic in caudal epidural space
• It is meant for paediatric patients less than 8 years of age

• Apex of an equilateral triangle formed by joining two posterior superior iliac spine as the base.

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent anger and emotional outbursts and diagnosed as “emotionally unstable” personality disorder. What is the psychotherapy of choice?
questions.solution:

Dialectical behavioural therapy

(Ref : Kaplan Psychiatry pg 751) 

DIALECTICAL BEHAVIOR THERAPY.

A particular form of psychotherapy called dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) has been used for patients with borderline personality disorder (also known as emotionally unstable personality disorder in ICD-10), especially those with parasuicidal behavior, such as frequent cutting.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the psychiatrist at the insistence of her boss because she constantly misses important deadlines. The woman states that everyone at work is lazy and that no one lives up to her own standards for perfection. She is angry when the physician starts the interview 3 minutes later than the appointed time. During the interview, she appears very rigid and stubborn.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anankastic 

Patients with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder/anankastic PD are preoccupied with orderliness, perfection, and control. They are often so preoccupied with details, lists, and order that they lose sight of the forest for focusing on the trees. Their concern with perfectionism makes it difficult for them to complete projects in a timely manner. They are often perceived as rigid and stubborn.

questions.text: All are not true about korsakoff’s syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Confabulation, apathy, passivity are often prominent symptoms

 (Ref : Kaplan Psychiatry Pg 720) Korsakoff’s syndrome is an amnestic syndrome caused by thiamine deficiency, most commonly associated with the poor nutritional habits of people with chronic alcohol abuse. Other causes of poor nutrition (e.g., starvation), gastric carcinoma, hemodialysis, hyperemesis gravidarum, prolonged IV hyperalimentation, and gastric plication can also result in thiamine deficiency. Korsakoff’s syndrome is often associated with Wernicke’s encephalopathy, which is the associated syndrome of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Patients with Korsakoff’s syndrome typically demonstrate a change in personality as well, such that they display a lack of initiative, diminished spontaneity, and a lack of interest or concern. These changes appear frontal lobe–like, similar to the personality change ascribed to patients with frontal lobe lesions or degeneration. Indeed, such patients often demonstrate executive function deficits on neuropsychological tasks involving attention, planning, set shifting, and inferential reasoning consistent with frontal pattern injuries. For this reason, Korsakoff’s syndrome is not a pure memory disorder, although it certainly is a good paradigm of the more common clinical presentations for the amnestic syndrome. The onset of Korsakoff’s syndrome can be gradual. Recent memory tends to be affected more than is remote memory, but this feature is variable. Confabulation, apathy, and passivity are often prominent symptoms in the syndrome. With treatment, patients may remain amnestic for up to 3 months and then gradually improve over the ensuing year. Administration of thiamine may prevent the development of additional amnestic symptoms, but the treatment seldom reverses severe amnestic symptoms when they are present. Approximately onethird to one-fourth of all patients recover completely, and approximately one-fourth of all patients have no improvement of their symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is intact in “Amnestic syndrome”?

Orientation

Amnestic disorders can be distinguished from delirium because they occur in the absence of a disturbance of consciousness (no disorientation) and are striking for the relative preservation of other cognitive domains.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 6 weeks gestation presents with heavy vaginal bleeding and an open cervix. TVS shows no fetal pole. What is the most appropriate management?

Surgical evacuation

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with excessive vomiting and vaginal bleeding at 12 weeks. Uterus is 16 weeks in size. USG shows “cluster of grapes” pattern. Diagnosis?

Complete hydatidiform mole

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with painless vaginal bleeding at 32 weeks. Fetal heart sounds are normal. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Placenta previa.

Painless bleeding in second half of pregnancy could be due to placenta previa or vasa previa but in vasa previa, there would be fetal blood loss leading to fetal distress. In this case, the fetal heart sounds are normal and hence the chances of placenta previa are more.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 34 weeks with preeclampsia has a seizure. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

IV magnesium sulfate

Explanation: Magnesium sulfate is first-line for seizure treatment in eclampsia, per RCOG (2021) guidelines.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 woman at 28 weeks gestation is found to have fasting blood glucose of 110 mg/dL and 2-hour postprandial level of 170 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:

Gestational Diabetes Mellitus

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman planning pregnancy is advised to start folic acid. What is the recommended daily dose?

400 mcg

Explanation: A daily dose of 400 mcg folic acid is recommended for all women to prevent neural tube defects, per WHO and FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: A 28-year-old Rh-negative primigravida at 10 weeks gestation has a threatened miscarriage. What is the most appropriate management?

Administer 50 mcg Anti-D immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents at 35 weeks of pregnancy with heavy bleeding and hypotension. She is diagnosed with placenta accreta. What is the most appropriate management?

Immediate cesarean section and hysterectomy

Explanation: Placenta accreta involves abnormal attachment of the placenta to the uterine wall, often requiring cesarean section and hysterectomy to control bleeding and prevent further complications.

Speculum exam

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a part of the Rotterdam criteria for diagnosing PCOS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Insulin resistance

The Rotterdam criteria for diagnosing Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) require the presence of two out of the following three criteria:

Hyperandrogenism: This can be either clinically (e.g., skin manifestations) or through biochemical tests showing high testosterone levels.

Ovulation dysfunction: This includes irregular menstrual cycles (oligo/amenorrhea) or anovulation.
Polycystic ovaries: Identified through ultrasound imaging.

questions.text: A 37 years old P3L3 patient has come with a history of post coital bleeding since last 3 months. On examination, it was found that she has a large cervical growth of 5 cm. It was spreading till the parametrial tissue but not involving the ureters or the lateral pelvic wall. On biopsy, there was a large cell non keratinising squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following is the best treatment for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Chemoradiation therapy.

This is a case of cervical cancer with Stage 2B. It is not to be operated. It is to be treated with chemoradiation therapy. Advanced cervical cancers are treated by chemotherapy. Early cervical cancers require surgery +/- chemoradiation therapy.

questions.text: A 62 years old post-menopausal patient was found to have an ovarian tumour of 5 cm in the right ovary. Her CA-125 is 1230 IU/L. Staging laparotomy was done and it was found that it was in one ovary. Peritoneal washing was negative, capsule was intact and surface of the tumour was smooth and cancer-free. Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy was done and the histopathology report revealed serous cystadenocarcinoma of well differentiated type. What additional step is required in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

No further treatment is necessary.

This is an ovarian cancer with Stage 1 A, well differentiated cancer (grade 1 cancer). Surgery alone is sufficient in such cases. There is no need of giving chemotherapy or radiotherapy in these cases.

questions.text: As per the latest SAGE guideline by WHO, what is the number of doses of HPV vaccine required?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1-2 doses for the age group of 9-20 years, 2 doses for the age group of >20-45 years.

SAGE recommends updating dose schedules for HPV as follows:

One or two-dose schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9-14

One or two-dose schedule for young women aged 15-20

Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 20.

Immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV, should receive three doses if feasible, and if not at least two doses. There is limited evidence regarding the efficacy of a single dose in this group.

questions.text: A 63 years old post-menopausal patient has post-menopausal bleeding. On TVS, there was a polypoidal growth in the fundal region with endometrial thickness 1mm on the remaining walls of uterus. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hysteroscopy guided fractional curettage and polypectomy

In post-menopausal bleeding, the first line of investigation is trans vaginal sonography. If the sonography shows any local growth in the endometrium then the patient is not subjected to screening test called as office endometrial aspiration. The patient is directly subjected to hysteroscopy and polypectomy and fractional curettage which will be diagnostic as well as therapeutic.

questions.text: In order to confirm the diagnosis of suspected cancer, which one of the following growths should not be subjected to biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ovarian growth

If ovarian biopsy is done, it will lead to rupture of the capsule and the probable cancer may spread till the peritoneal areas. So, ovarian biopsy is not done. Exploratory laparotomy and frozen section histopathology are done in these cases.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a tubal patency test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hysteroscopy

Hysteroscopy is done to visualise the inner aspect of the uterus. Tubal openings are visualised well but whether the tube is open or not cannot be commented on hysteroscopy alone. Hence it is not a tubal patency test.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female presents with fever, weight loss, elevated levels of ACE levels with hilar lymphadenopathy on X-ray, the most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sarcoidosis
Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease commonly affecting young adults, especially females around the age of 30-40. It presents with symptoms like fever, weight loss, and characteristic bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy seen on chest X-ray. Elevated serum angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels are a supportive diagnostic marker, reflecting granuloma burden. The combination of these clinical features and radiologic findings makes sarcoidosis the most probable diagnosis in this patient.

questions.text: Identify the abnormality found in the ultrasound image shown:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Phrygian cap
The Phrygian cap is a normal anatomical variant of the gallbladder where the fundus is folded back on the body, creating a characteristic folded appearance on ultrasound. It is benign and usually asymptomatic, often discovered incidentally during imaging. On ultrasound, it appears as a fold or kink in the gallbladder wall without any mass or abnormal shadowing, which distinguishes it from pathological conditions.

questions.text: Shown finding on USG is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Spina bifida
The ultrasound finding shown is most likely a lemon sign or a banana sign, which are classic sonographic markers associated with spina bifida, specifically open neural tube defects like myelomeningocele. The lemon sign refers to the scalloping or inward concavity of the fetal skull bones, and the banana sign refers to the shape of the cerebellum due to downward displacement caused by spinal defects. These findings help in the prenatal diagnosis of spina bifida.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with shown appearance of face & on CT brain is given. Shown characteristic is associated with which of the following condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sturge Weber syndrome
Sturge Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by a facial port-wine stain (usually involving the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve), leptomeningeal angiomas visible on brain imaging (often on CT or MRI), and associated neurological symptoms such as seizures, hemiparesis, and developmental delay. The CT brain in Sturge Weber syndrome often shows cortical calcifications with a characteristic "tram-track" appearance due to calcified leptomeningeal angiomas. The facial appearance with port-wine stain and the CT findings are classical for this syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following modalities use remote afterloading?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Brachytherapy
Remote afterloading is a technique used in brachytherapy, a form of radiation therapy where a radioactive source is placed close to or inside the tumor. In remote afterloading, the radioactive source is loaded into the applicator after it has been positioned in the patient, minimizing radiation exposure to healthcare personnel. This method allows precise delivery of high doses of radiation directly to the tumor while sparing surrounding healthy tissues, and remote afterloading enhances safety by reducing radiation exposure to staff.

choices.text: Nasal washing for influenza virus and respiratory syncytial virus

questions.text: A 2 yr old boy is presented to the emergency department at 3 AM with a chief complaint of fever and cough. His respiratory rate is 36 breaths/min, his temperature is 39°C, and his pulse oximetry reading is 96%. On physical examination he has a barky cough and stridor only with crying. He is well hydrated, able to drink, and consolable. What is the appropriate next step in patient management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dexamethasone
The effectiveness of oral corticosteroids in viral croup is well established. Corticosteroids decrease the edema in the laryngeal mucosa through their anti-inflammatory action. Oral steroids are beneficial, even in mild croup, as measured by reduced hospitalization, shorter duration of hospitalization, and reduced need for subsequent interventions such as epinephrine administration.
Most studies that demonstrated the efficacy of oral dexamethasone used a single dose of 0.6 mg/kg; a dose as low as 0.15 mg/ kg may be just as effective. Intramuscular dexamethasone and nebulized budesonide have an equivalent clinical effect; oral dosing of dexamethasone is as effective as intramuscular administration. A single dose of oral prednisolone is less effective. There are no controlled studies examining the effectiveness of multiple doses of corticosteroids.

questions.text: A 5 yr old boy presents with pubic hair development. He is tall and has increased pigmentation of his genitalia and phallic enlargement. Blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Measurement of which of the following hormones would be most likely to be diagnostic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

11-deoxycortisol
11ß-Hydroxylase deficiency accounts for approximately 5% of cases of adrenal hyperplasia; its incidence has been estimated as 1/250,000 to 1/100,000. Although cortisol is not synthesized efficiently, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal, and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by the intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency such   as hypotension, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia. Approximately 65% of patients become hypertensive, although this can take several years to develop. Hypertension is probably a consequence of elevated levels of deoxycorticosterone, which has mineralocorticoid activity. Infants may transiently develop signs of mineralocorticoid deficiency after treatment with hydrocortisone is instituted. This is presumably due to sudden suppression of  deoxycorticosterone secretion in a patient with atrophy of the zona glomerulosa caused by chronic suppression of renin activity. All signs and symptoms of  androgen excess that are found in 21- hydroxylase deficiency may also occur in 11-hydroxylase deficiency. Plasma levels of 11-deoxycortisol and  deoxycorticosterone are elevated

questions.text: A 11 yr old girl has had difficulty in getting out of chairs and combing her hair for 3 mo. Physical examination reveals a Gowers sign, in addition to tenderness over the quadriceps muscles and 4/5 strength. Also, there is a faint erythematous rash over both upper eyelids. The most likely diagnosis for this patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

juvenile dermatomyositis. 
Children with juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM) present with either rash, insidious onset of weakness, or both. Fevers, dysphagia or dysphonia, arthritis, muscle tenderness, and fatigue are also commonly reported at diagnosis. Rash develops as the 1st symptom in 50% of cases and appears concomitant with weakness only 25% of the time. Children often exhibit extreme photosensitivity to ultraviolet light exposure with generalized erythema in sun-exposed areas. The characteristic heliotrope rash is a blue-violet discoloration of the eyelids that may be associated with periorbital edema. Weakness associated with JDM is often insidious and difficult to differentiate from fatigue at onset. It is typically symmetric, affecting proximal muscles such as the neck flexors, shoulder girdle, and hip flexors. Parents may report difficulty climbing stairs, combing hair, and getting out of bed. Examination reveals inability to perform a sit-up, head lag in a child after infancy, and Gower sign (use of hands on thighs to stand from a sitting position.) Patients with JDM may roll to the side rather than sit straight up from lying to compensate for truncal weakness. Approximately half of children exhibit muscle tenderness as a result of muscle inflammation. Diagnosis of dermatomyositis requires the presence of characteristic rash as well as at least three signs of muscle inflammation and weakness.

choices.text: Give NaHCO3 1 mEq/kg IV to correct acidosis
Administer normal saline 20 mL/kg bolus over 30 min

questions.text: A previously healthy 6 yr old child presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of malaise, poor oral intake, diarrhea, and decreased urine output. Physical examination reveals tachycardia, dry mucous membranes, and sunken eyes. Results of initial laboratory studies include BUN 65 mg/dL, potassium 5.5 mEq/L, bicarbonate 14 mEq/L, and serum creatinine 3.0 mg/dL. The most appropriate next step in treatment is to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Prerenal
Prerenal ARF, also called prerenal azotemia, is characterized by diminished effective circulating arteria volume, which leads to inadequate renal perfusion and a decreased GFR. Evidence of kidney damage is absent. Common causes of prerenal ARF include dehydration, sepsis, hemorrhage, severe hypoalbuminemia, and cardiac failure. If the underlying cause of the renal hypoperfusion is reversed promptly, renal function returns to normal. If hypoperfusion is sustained, intrinsic renal parenchymal damage can develop.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl with a history of developmental delay presents with her foster parents for an evaluation following removal from her home by a social services agency due to medical neglect. Her height, weight, and head circumference are all below the 3 percentile. Facial features include short palpebral fissures; mild ptosis; a shortened nose associated with midface hypoplasia; a long, thin philtrum; and a thin upper lip.
Which of the following is most likely to be identified during additional evaluation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Ventricular septal defect

The patient has clinical findings consistent with fetal alcohol syndrome, the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability, with an incidence of 1–2/1,000 births. At birth, affected infants have evidence of intrauterine growth retardation with persistence of growth deficiency in height, weight, and head circumference throughout life. Diagnosis of fetal alcohol syndrome is dependent upon clinical findings as there are no specific biomarkers of alcohol exposure. Facial features may include short palpebral fissures; a smooth, thin philtrum; a thin vermilion border of the upper lip; a shortened nose associated with midface hypoplasia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in a cyanotic spell?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Calcium has no role in pathogenesis of the spell
Tet spells — Hypercyanotic (or "tet") spells present as periods of profound cyanosis that occur because of episodes of dynamic severe RVOT obstruction. They typically arise when an infant becomes agitated or in older, uncorrected children after vigorous exercise.
Management of hypercyanotic "tet" spells requires a rapid and aggressive stepwise approach:
●Place the patient in a knee-chest position.
●Administer oxygen.
●If these fail, administer an intravenous (IV) fluid bolus (normal saline 10 to 20 mL/kg) and a dose of narcotic. We typically use IV morphine (0.1 mg/kg per dose) for this purpose; intranasal fentanyl or midazolam have also been described as successful interventions in patients with difficult IV access
●If the above measures fail, administer an IV beta blocker (eg, propranolol 0.1 mg/kg per dose or esmolol 0.1 mg/kg per dose). If single doses are ineffective, a continuous IV infusion of esmolol (50 to 75 mcg/kg/min) can be provided.
●If beta blocker therapy is insufficient, administer IV phenylephrine (bolus dose of 5 to 20 mcg/kg per dose, followed by continuous infusion).
●If all of these measures fail, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation support (ECMO), emergency complete surgical repair, or an emergency aorticopulmonary shunt is necessary.

choices.text: An intramural duodenal hematoma identified on abdominal ultrasound
Acute distension of the gallbladder identified on abdominal ultrasound
A renal artery thrombosis identified on Doppler ultrasound
Dilation of the aortic root identified on echocardiogram
Multiple dilated loops of large bowel with bubbly linear gas collections within the bowel wall

questions.text: An irritable and febrile 3-year-old boy with a morbilliform-like rash and bulbar conjunctival injection is hospitalized and subsequently found to have a left coronary artery aneurysm. Which of the following is most likely to be identified during additional evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute distension of the gallbladder identified on abdominal ultrasound
The patient has clinical signs and symptoms consistent with Kawasaki disease (a.k.a.
mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome). Gallbladder hydrops may also occur in the first 2
weeks of illness and is typically self-limited. It may present as a right upper quadrant mass on
physical examination and appears markedly enlarged (overdistended) and balloon-shaped on
abdominal ultrasound.
